definition: to coexist/coexistence
two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jin1] (old)
surname Li
to stand/to set up/to establish/to lay down/to draw up/at once/immediately
the two cannot exist together (idiom); irreconcilable differences/incompatible standpoints
the two cannot exist together (idiom); irreconcilable differences/incompatible standpoints
lit. Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉[Shu3 Han4] and Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4] cannot coexist (idiom)/fig. two enemies cannot live under the same sky/(former KMT slogan against CCP) "gentlemen and thieves cannot coexist"

sentences.english: Pride does not consort with poverty.
You and I are at daggers drawn.
sentences.chinese: 我们的仇恨不共戴天，我与你势不两立。

sentences.english: I'm not talking about mourning versus laughing.
sentences.chinese: 我并没有说，哀恸和欢笑势不两立。

sentences.english: The world at the time was divided into two implacably opposed blocks and the Cold War was at its iciest.
sentences.chinese: 那时世界分成势不两立的两大阵营，冷战正处在冰点。

sentences.english: These 2 characteristics that contradict it is coexist with the high dimension.
sentences.chinese: 在高维两立着相反的这些2个特性。

sentences.english: When it found out, the cat vowed to be the rat's natural enemy.
sentences.chinese: 当它发现被老鼠骗了，便发誓与老鼠誓不两立。

sentences.english: I didn't expect them to be at daggers drawn over such a trivial thing.
sentences.chinese: 我没料到他们为这一点小事竟会如此势不两立。
